title: Friday, 28th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

The final ML before we take a two week break

PM11:01am

To sort our lives out

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Try to

PM11:01am

The newsflow is nuts right

PM11:01am

Sheesh, the stuff overnight

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Suppose we have to go with the obv pic

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

If you haven't read the New Yorker piece, you should

11:02 am
PM11:02am

https://www.newyor...s-and-steve-bannon

BE11:02am

Mooch's move from a niche joke in financial circles to a global joke has been one of the best things to happen over the past month.

PM11:03am

Then there was the Obamacare stuff in the Senate

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Which peaked in the early hours, I time

PM11:04am

But because we run AV on a Slack channel we in London get to catch up with the running commentary provided by our US colleagues overnight

PM11:04am

Here's Cardiff at 6.19am London time...

11:04 am
PM11:04am

HOLY SHIT it seems mccain is against the skinny repeal and refuses to vote for it. I guess everything could change again tomorrow, but pence (who was there for the tiebreaker) has left the chamber and mcconnell apparently walked off

[6:19]
man, i did not have mccain saves obamacare in my pool in 2009

[6:20]
jesus, vote still stalled

[6:20]
this is awful

[6:24]
they might go on all night

[6:27]
they're voting -- happening right now, can't express how crazy this night has been

[6:30]
THAT'S IT MCCAIN VOTES NO

PM11:04am

Anyway...

undefined
11:04 am
PM11:05am

Nuts

BE11:05am

I'm fascinated by McCain, and the conscience he keeps in a box next to Schrödinger's cat.

PM11:05am

Yeah, i know

11:05 am
BE11:05am

But, yes, it does cast what we do in a rather duller light. There's no competing with politics right now.

BE11:05am

Anyone want to talk stocks fun?

PM11:06am

We should try and focus on markets if we can

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Quite a lot going on for a Friday

PM11:06am

Companies trying to get stuff out the door before people go on hols

PM11:06am

Can we start with a good news story?

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Please!

PM11:07am

However, the change in the company’s ownership structure will result in a number of family members leaving the business. Tarak’s wife, Nusrat, who was being paid a salary of £15,000 as a product adviser, has resigned after the couple banked about £25m. Sheraz’s wife, Romana, is giving up her £15,000 a year job as a social media adviser after the couple sold shares worth more than £20m.

BE11:07am

........ ?

11:07 am
PM11:07am

That's from a Guardian piece on Quiz

PM11:07am

https://www.thegua...tail-chain-at-200m

BE11:07am

Ah!

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Frock shop that's joined AIM this morning

BE11:08am

Yep. Taraq Razan’s company. Party frock specialist.

PM11:08am

Normally we bitch about online fashion

11:08 am
BE11:08am

But it's not online fashion.

PM11:08am

Especially when a float involves taking a lot of money off the table

PM11:08am

Yeah sure, on and off line

11:08 am
PM11:08am

But this is such a rags to riches tale

PM11:09am

Immigrants from Pakistan to Scotland

BE11:09am

It's a chain of shops -- lots of them -- with a website. And it's a good story, certainly.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Razan’s a Glasgow rag trade merchant who was looking for a way to compete with Primark

PM11:09am

Here's Tarak

PM11:09am

http://prideofpaki...me/orgsize_26Tariq Ramzan.jpg

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Sorry, linking broken

BE11:10am

The guy we can't see due to a broken link landed on the niche of dresses for occasions — birthday parties, weddings, etc — where aspiration and hard discounting don’t really align.

BE11:10am

No prospectus I can find. The admission document is a also dead link:

11:10 am
BE11:10am

http://www.quizgro...vestor-relations/#

PM11:10am

Try this http://www.quizgro...t-20-July-2017.pdf

BE11:10am

Aha! Thanks.

11:10 am
PM11:11am

They've raised £103m

BE11:11am

Yep. Headlines are £102.7m of gross proceeds at a price of 161p, of which £92.1m of gross proceeds will go to the selling shareholders and £10.6m of gross proceeds for the company.

PM11:11am

£92m of which gets shared out amongst the family

11:11 am
PM11:11am

And the stock has Rocket

Quiz PLC (QUIZ:LSE): Last: 196.38, up 196.38 (), High: 196.75, Low: 180.00, Volume: 6.07m
BE11:12am

Though the family retain a significant interest. By the website -- note I've not read the prospectus yet, having not previously found it -- CEO Tarak retains 20%, Sheraz (COO), Haris and Mussarat have another 20% or so.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Up 23% from the placing price

PM11:12am

Panmure handled the float

BE11:13am

Interesting business, established and in a decent niche, fairly tight free float ........ haven't seen any proper financials so can't say a single thing about the price.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

Sure

PM11:13am

We can just keep an eye on it

BE11:14am

There's a good backgrounder from Drapers a while back though. https://www.draper...ld/7017619.article

11:14 am
undefined
BE11:15am

.... so, that's the good news portion of the show done. What now?

PM11:15am

Hmm

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Footsie off 55 points

PM11:15am

Only a handful of Footsie risers

PM11:15am

BT getting hit hard

11:15 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 304.70, down 11.45 (-3.62%), High: 313.15, Low: 301.35, Volume: 9.84m
PM11:16am

Q1s here https://www.invest...1707280700083997M/

BE11:16am

And they're fine if you ignore the dirty great charge

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Which it appears the market won't.

BE11:18am

The big negative seems to be the DT-Orange warranty claim

PM11:18am

£225m

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Settlement

BE11:18am

£225m related to the Italian profit warning.

PM11:18am

Ah right

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The charge is about 2p off EPS.

BE11:19am

And perhaps more importantly, it's another unflagged and (at least to me) totally unexpected headwind to the BT story.

BE11:20am

For what used to be a utility, BT often seems like a black box of liabilities and costs.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

This is so true

BE11:21am

So, sure, KPIs look okay (not brilliant) and FY guidance is unchanged but the fuzz over forecasts demands a discount.

BE11:21am

Let me get some sellside to summarise the main points.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Polo Tang at UBS.

BE11:22am

BT Q1 results modestly ahead of expectations, announced the merger of its
Consumer/EE units and has agreed a £225m settlement with DT/Orange. Q1 revenues
grew +0.2% £5,849m (cons £5,812m) with EBITDA –2.5% to £1,785m (cons
£1,762m). Normalised EFCF was £556m (cons £254m) with the beat driven by a
notable beat in working capital that will reverse later in the year. We see the merger of
Consumer/EE as a logical next step given the move towards convergence and the move
should yield additional synergies over time. BT has agreed a £225m settlement with
DT/Orange in relation to warranties for the EE transaction given the correction in the BT
share price as a result of the BT Italia warning.

BE11:22am

As expected, Public Sector and Global Services drove the bulk of the EBITDA declines,
although the latter was notably weaker than expected due to Italy. However, there was
strong EBITDA growth at EE as it benefited from merger synergies as well as a beat in
Other. Retail broadband net adds were +19k (vs +83k/+29k in Q3/Q4) and we reiterate
our view that the UK broadband market is maturing and competition is
increasing. Mobile post-paid net adds for the group were +210k (after +276k/+192k in
Q3/Q4) and we think BT has benefited from Business mobile growth.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

BT has re-iterated FY-18 guidance of £7.5-7.6bn in EBITDA (cons £7.55bn) and £2.7-
2.9bn in normalised EFCF (cons £2.72bn). We would not expect significant changes to
consensus estimates at this stage - the £225m settlement with DT/Orange will be
treated as a specific item/exceptional.

BE11:23am

The modest beat for Q1 is encouraging but we note the shares have rallied into these
numbers. Separately, uncertainties remain over medium-term EFCF with lack of visibility
on both pension costs and capex. BT offers a 6% calendarised EFCF yield for 2018
(post-pension costs), rising to 9% on a pre-pension basis - these multiples assume no
material step up in capex.

BE11:23am

And Citi.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Retail broadband net adds slipped to +19k but at a respectable
share of 55%, while Openreach saw line loss of -94k probably due to slower HH
growth and overbuilding. Retail fibre adds were 170k and uptake rose to 55%.
Postpaid net adds held up well at 210k and at 1.1% churn remains low. B&PS order
intake in the quarter was up 81% yoy to £1.2bn after a rise of 18% last quarter.

BE11:24am

mplications — Fine at the headline level this set of figures look less good under
the surface. Consumer's weak margin print will surprise few but another charge,
Openreach line loss and a weak order book outside B&PS offset better news at EE
where cost savings may be arriving earlier rather than exceeding expectations.

PM11:24am

Just looking at the chart for this

11:24 am
PM11:25am

Bar the recent small rally it's been down all the way for two years now

PM11:25am

Not good for what should and could be a boring utility

BE11:25am

On the pension hole, here's the conference call .....

11:25 am
BE11:25am

The IAS 19 valuation of the pension deficit this quarter was GBP 8 billion, net of tax. We are currently engaged in constructive discussions with the
BT PS trustees on the triannual pension valuation, including the level and structure of deficit contributions, and we aim to complete discussions
in the first half of calendar year 2018.
We have also opened discussions with scheme members and the unions regarding the review of the BT Pension Scheme, and we put forward a
case for change as a basis to discuss future benefits.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:27am

We should provably not read anything into that, no matter how tempting it is to.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Gavin's been CEO since 2013, and was central to its move into telly rights bidding before that. I'm wondering how long shareholders stay on his side.

undefined
PM11:28am

We could trudge on through trading statements

11:28 am
PM11:28am

But we should also note Frontier Developments

PM11:29am

A company we tend to be quite nice about

PM11:29am

Given that they came along to Camp Alphaville a couple of times

11:29 am
PM11:29am

This Tencent is something, no?

PM11:29am

https://www.invest...1707280700033473M/

PM11:30am

Tencent taking 9.9%

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Ooh. That's interesting.

PM11:30am

Actually it's new stock, so nets out at 9%

PM11:30am

Tencent has subscribed for 3,386,252 newly issued ordinary shares of 0.5 pence each ("the New Shares") in the Company at a price of 523.2 pence per share. The price paid per share has been calculated as the last 20 trading days volume weighted average price (VWAP) immediately prior to subscription. The New Shares represent approximately 9.9% of the issued share capital of the Company prior to the issue of the New Shares, and 9.0% after the issue of the New Shares.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

This is cracking stuff for David Braben

PM11:31am

Hence...

Frontier Developments PLC (FDEV:LSE): Last: 600.00, up 75 (+14.29%), High: 614.00, Low: 600.00, Volume: 60.74k
11:31 am
PM11:32am

I don't have any broker stuff on this

BE11:32am

@Mouselet, I could be wrong here but I think Tencent has a whole load of minority stakes in developers.

PM11:32am

But it's one to keep an eye on

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Hang on, let me see if I do.

BE11:33am

Tencent, one of the world's leading internet and interactive entertainment companies, has made a strategic £17.7m investment in Frontier via the issue of new equity and in so doing provides compelling validation of Frontier’s strategy and ability to execute.

BE11:33am

That's Finncap, house broker.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

And this is Numis ...... which I think is also house? Dunno. Haven't checked.

BE11:34am

This is clearly a very positive
endorsement from a major global player in the entertainment industry; Tencent has
existing holdings in Supercell (Clash of Clans), Riot Games (League of Legends),
Epic Games (Unreal game engine, Gears of War) and a broad range of other gaming,
internet and entertainment businesses. The proceeds will be used by Frontier to
augment existing resources and accelerate the scale-up of existing operations
and franchises. In addition, the Tencent relationship should support Frontier in
capitalising on the large and growing market in China, through local expertise and
access to Tencent's distribution capabilities including the WeGame online store.
Given the recent positive trading updates in April and June, and the impending
launch of a third franchise, Frontier is showing very strong momentum and we
upgrade our target price reflecting a the strategic opportunity resulting from the
Tencent investment. 4.3x EV:Sales equates to a 605p TP (was 466p).

BE11:34am

Forecasts unchanged, albeit we see scope for "accelerated investment" to potentially
deliver faster investment and ramp-up for future franchises. It also provides Frontier
with significant strategic flexibility in terms of organic and inorganic investment.
However, for now we leave our P&L numbers unchanged, although our EPS, share
count and balance sheet reflect the incremental 3.4m shares and £17.7m cash.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Chinese PC and console market growing 18% and 180% respectively last year, Numis says.

BE11:35am

The latter, clearly, off a very low base.

BE11:35am

And Steam's user base nearly trebled in two years.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Good market to get into.

BE11:36am

● 4.3x Dec-18 EV:Sales yields 605p TP. Peer multiples have increased slightly, and we
have also re-cut our peers slightly to remove more of those with hardware interests;
midpoint of the simple and weighted average Dec-18 EV:Sales is 4.3x although we see
significant further upside if the franchise release pattern enables Frontier to build on
FY19's £60m+ revenue; 4.3x May-19's £62.9m would give a 753p TP.

undefined
11:37 am
BE11:37am

What else we got? Just Sell, maybe?

PM11:37am

Yeah, what's going on there?

BE11:38am

We didn't have time to note Just Eat's reverse ferret in yesterday's session, due to the 10,000 other results on the tape

11:37 am
PM11:38am

Noticeably week these past few days

PM11:38am

What have they reverse ferretted on?

BE11:38am

Big chains

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Opening up the platform to the economy-of-scale takeaway places, who'd previously favoured Deliver mostly.

BE11:40am

Deliveroo, I mean. The Mac's auto correct typing is extremely annoying, isn't it?

BE11:41am

Anyway, Barclays downgrades in response.

11:41 am
PM11:41am

So, what -- are people worried about investment costs stacking up here?

PM11:41am

Let's here Barclays

BE11:41am

Just Eat’s Q2 release gave us two pieces of new information: Firstly, the Q1 UK order
growth slowdown has been contained, with Q2 showing a decent sequential
improvement, and the second half looks achievable – this was a positive. Secondly,
there was an EBITDA margin miss as the business looks to reinvest across branded
restaurant relationships (including delivery partnerships), regional rollouts in
overseas businesses and additional sales & marketing. This is creating some risk
around H2 profit – this was a negative. We also question whether becoming closer
to branded restaurants could cause some frustration in the independent restaurant
customer base. Given the above, we see limited opportunity to increase our price
target and therefore, following the stock’s run, we downgrade to Equal Weight

11:41 am
BE11:42am

Investments ramping up: Gross profit margin dropped by 590bp y/y, largely due to
Skip, but also due to some internal investment in logistics partnerships. In addition,
OpEx investments are going into the business and this is weighing on EBITDA. In our
scenario analysis we conclude that, without revenue outperformance there is some
downside risk to EBITDA guidance. We reduce our EBITDA forecasts by 3-5%.

BE11:42am

You'll remember JE was the asset-light model that was a shopfront for chicken shops with access to their own moped.

PM11:42am

Okay, this makes sense -- all the independents will be up in arms

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Or may be

BE11:43am

Yep. The story's changing a bit, and at a time when the consensus expectation is for Just Eat to squeeze up its rake rather than deliver much more sales growth.

BE11:44am

There's some grumbling this morning about JE going for "margin optimisation" rather than land grab

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Though that's from brokers I can't quote, so instead have Morgan Stanley.

BE11:45am

What weliked: UK order growth decelerated by c.3% underlying this quarter,a
milder pace than in previous quarters. The comps in Q3are easier so we raise our
estimate for the year to 17%. Since the company seems to be decelerating at a
slightly milder pace than we forecasted, we adjust our forward looking forecasts
to a 3-5%-deceleration p.a. The company raised the revenue target by £15m,
partly on SkipTheDishes (c.£8m better than we expected), slightly better growth
in other "established" markets (although on almostno incremental EBITDA) and
FX. Our revenueforecasts increase by1-3% in 2017-18.

BE11:46am

What we didn't like: The deceleration in orders in Australia was worse than we
expected,having gone from 20% in Q1 to 12% in Q2. Whilst the company plans to
extend its geographic reach & execute on the rebranding and replatforming in H2,
we think the slowdown is largely driven by greater competition from UberEATS
& Deliveroo in its core cities. In France, our proprietary data shows that Deliveroo
has 3.3k restaurants vs. Just Eat at 3.8k and it is adding them at a faster pace.
Finally, the better revenuegrowth is not paired with higher EBITDA margins.
Even in the UK, where the company benefitted from a 1%-point increase in
commission in Q1, margins remained broadly unchanged.For the company to
meet consensus EBITDA of £164m (guidance is £157-163m,unchanged), it would
need to deliver a higher incremental margin in H2vs. H1. However, the company
won't be benefitting as much from FX or commission increases, it will be
executing on the rebranding & replatforming in Australia,and it will launch the XFactor
campaign so weforecast EBITDA of £159m towards the bottom end of guidance.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Whatkeeps us cautious: Whilst we raise our forecasts and our revenue
expectation is slightly above consensus, our underlying EBITDA forecasts are 3%and 5% below consensus in 2017 and 2018. As Just Eat continues to tackle
competition in some of its core markets, it will continue to spend on marketing
and other consumer initiatives to drive growth. As it fights the three sided
delivery platforms, its third party driver solution to deliver branded restaurant
food is proving to be costly and not that effective (at least yet), in our view. Just
Eat added 190 branded restaurants in H1 compared to UberEATS which added
150 McDonald's in one month. Deliveroo has close to 9k restaurants (source:
AlphaWise) creeping closer to the 27k at Just Eat.

BE11:48am

The endgame, of course, is for new CEO Peter Plumb to add the SkipTheDishes model of centralised mopeds to other markets and we have to tear up all the capex and margin forecasts again.

BE11:49am

But that's maybe a year or two off. For the moment, you're paying 32x next year for an industry leader whose figures still look uncertain given how fast the market's changing.

11:49 am
undefined
PM11:50am

This Mitchells & Butler figs have gone down badly -- warning of margin pressure

PM11:50am

Stock's off 9% now

11:50 am
PM11:50am

But it's very volatile, no?

Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 245.20, down 24.8 (-9.19%), High: 270.19, Low: 245.20, Volume: 574.08k
BE11:50am

Wait, what? Wasn't Michells yesterday or am I getting confused?

11:50 am
PM11:50am

https://www.invest...1707270700062180M/

PM11:51am

Oh yes, sorry

PM11:51am

I need a break

11:51 am
PM11:51am

So yesterday the stock moved from circa 225p to 265p

PM11:52am

And now it's back at 245p

BE11:52am

Yeah, thought so. M&B pinged up 16% or so yesterday on in-line figures and a pension settlement that was better than feared .......

11:52 am
BE11:52am

.... which looked extremely generous.

BE11:52am

..... today's correction returns things to normality.

BE11:53am

No free float though, so volatile.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

ok

undefined
BE11:54am

Why are the ROTR talking about robo-doctors and online prescriptions?

11:53 am
PM11:54am

Someone started it with Alexa

BE11:55am

Oh. That doesn't really answer my question but I guess it's as good an answer as any.

PM11:55am

Idea that Amazon could turn Alexa into a talking doctor -- adn then deliver the meds

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Babylon diagnosis AI, as noted on the right, is quite impressive depending on how it's deployed. There's a rebadged NHS trial going on at the moment, if I'm not mistaken.

BE11:57am

As for online pharmacies ... I noticed a week or two ago that there are several pharmacies in Ladbroke Grove with signs in the window .....

BE11:58am

..... warning customers not to use a specific one, which I'll not name but it lives very near the top of a Google search .......

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Did it say why?

BE11:58am

..... who've apparently been positioning reps around the doors of chemists trying to nick their customers.

PM11:59am

Oh i see

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Which, in the literal shadow of Grenfell Tower, feels a bit dodgy.

PM11:59am

That sounds like a very expensive way for an online business to drum up customers

BE12:00pm

The whole online pharma area is a spot where regulation hasn't yet caught up with regulatory arbitrage. The health regulators in particular moves extremely slowly, through multiple branches that don't seem very good at talking to one another or defining their actual remits.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

They'll get there though. Eventually.

undefined
PM12:01pm

Look at the time

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Right -- thanks for joining us on the right

PM12:02pm

You'll all have to go cold turkey for a fortnight

PM12:02pm

Cos we are off

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Thumbs up

PM12:02pm

It will be good for you and good for us

BE12:03pm

(I'm still in the office and can fire up a session if, for example, Shell buys BP. But it'll be reluctantly.)

12:02 pm
PM12:03pm

We'll be back on Monday 14th

PM12:03pm

Unless something big happens

PM12:03pm

Bye

11:26 am
BE11:26am

That's Simon Lowth, FD, who I think led the call rather than Gavin Patterson.
